0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• premedicate with a mild laxative such as bisacodyl or lactulose the evening before administration and continue for 48 hours.
  • encourage liberal fluid intake prior to administration and while patient is receiving laxatives
  • Neuroendocrine tumor; Diagnosis: (planar imaging) 111 megabecquerels (3 millicuries) IV; premedicate with mild laxative the night before procedure and continue for 48 hours along with adequate hydration
  • Neuroendocrine tumor; Diagnosis: (SPECT imaging) 222 megabecquerels (6 millicuries) IV; premedicate with mild laxative the night before procedure and continue for 48 hours along with adequate hydration

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Neuroendocrine tumor; Diagnosis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Graves' disease

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• concomitant administration in total parenteral nutrition admixture or injection into TPN line not recommended
  • concomitant use with octreotide acetate may result in reduced sensitivity to indium In-111 pentetreotide; consider temporarily suspending octreotide therapy and monitor for withdrawal symptoms
  • insulinomas; severe hypoglycemia may occur; use of IV line and administration of IV glucose before and during administration recommended
  • radiation dose to thyroid, bladder, kidneys, and target organs, increased level, may occur; increase fluid intake before and 1 day after administration
  • renal insufficiency
  • radiopharmaceutical; handle with care and use safety measures to reduce radiation exposure to personnel and patient

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Bradyarrhythmia
  • Hematologic:Decreased hematocrit level, Decreased hemoglobin
  • Hepatic:Liver enzymes abnormal (less than 1%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Pentetreotide, a diethylenetriaminopentaacetic (DTPA) conjugate of octreotide (an analog of somatostatin), binds to somatostatin receptors on cell surfaces throughout the body. Tumors containing a high density of somatostatin receptors concentrate indium In 111-labeled pentetreotide. After clearance of blood activity, visualization of somatostatin receptor-positive tissue is achieved with scintigraphic imaging techniques.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • use proper procedures for handling and disposal of radiopharmaceuticals
  • use drug within 6 hours of preparation
  • wear waterproof gloves during handling procedure and perform all operations aseptically
  • place vial in lead dispensing shield (minimum wall thickness, 0.25 inch) with lid
  • remove contents of vial and with needle provided and shielded syringe and inject into reaction vial; gently swirl contents until pellet is dissolved and then incubate at or below 25 degrees C (77 degrees F) for a minimum of 30 minutes
  • preparation may be diluted to a maximum volume of 3 mL with 0.9% Sodium Chloride immediately prior to injection

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• quality scintigraphic images of somatostatin-containing tumor lesions are indicative of efficacy
  • no specific toxic monitoring has been determined

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may cause headache, dizziness, fever, arthralgia, nausea, sweating, or weakness.
  • Advise patient to stay hydrated and void as often as possible prior to and for at least 1 day after administration.
